metadata.sermon_title: God’s Alien Work in the Church—Isaiah 28:14-22
metadata.sermon_start_end: ON THIS Sunday just past, the last of the Christian year, we focused on Isaiah 10: — “Destruction is decreed, overflowing with righteousness.” Our text this weekday, in between the last and the first, continues that theme from Isaiah, the prophet most associated with Advent and Christmas [...] To follow him in humility, to steel ourselves for the lifelong battle, to serve him in the darkest hours of the night, to trust his right hand when all we can see is his left, “to attest and revere the justice and goodness of God” — this is our high calling. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on the Isaiah passage, specifically the 'strange deed' and 'alien work.' It attempts to find the unique point of the text (God's judgment as an alien work), but frequently drifts into general historical and theological illustrations (Lincoln, Luther) that overshadow the specific nuances of the Zion foundation stone in its original prophetic context.
quotes: The Lord will rise up as on Mount Perazim... to do his deed — strange is his deed! and to work his work — alien is his work!
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more on the specific imagery of the 'line' and 'plummet' in verse 17 to show what this text specifically says about divine architecture that other judgment texts do not.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The sermon lacks depth regarding the Hebrew context or the specific historical situation of the 'scoffers' in Jerusalem. It quickly pivots to systematic theology (Luther) and American history (Lincoln) rather than explaining what the text meant for the first readers under the threat of Assyria/Egypt.
quotes: Because of Luther, this passage has been enshrined in the pantheon of significant theological concepts.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the historical-critical background of the 'covenant with death' (likely the alliance with Egypt) to ground the exposition in the original context before moving to systematic categories.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the divisions in the Anglican/American church. It avoids 'general truths' by addressing specific ecclesiastical polarizations and the 'zeitgeist' of dismissal and disdain. The use of the Lincoln example provides a strong, albeit historical, application to the concept of national/ecclesial struggle.
quotes: I am troubled (as you are) about the divisions within the church on our continent... the increasing polarization and closing of channels of civilized communication.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Make the application even more specific to the 'scoffing' mentioned in the text—how does the modern church specifically 'scoff' at God's foundation?

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat block-like structure: text, then Lincoln, then Luther, then a personal anecdote. While the themes are consistent, the hearer is not always 'drawn into the text' as much as they are drawn into the preacher's theological library.
quotes: Alongside this I want to set another quotation.
One who did was Martin Luther. He fastened upon the text...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Instead of introducing Luther and Lincoln as external authorities, weave their insights directly into the line-by-line explanation of the Isaiah verses.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes 'misery' (judgment, alien work) and 'redemption' (the cornerstone). It avoids a 'too Christocentric' approach by maintaining the tension of God's wrath. Man is seen as the subject in his confusion and 'bonds.'
quotes: It is better to be struck by the left hand of God than to think that God has no plan.
Destruction is decreed, overflowing with righteousness.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'gratitude' part (sanctification/response) remains somewhat vague, focused on 'humility' rather than concrete new life.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is a strong point. The preacher explicitly rejects the 'God loves everybody' sentimentality and insists on the reality of judgment and the 'stumbling stone.' It takes the possibility of being 'lost' (temporal and eternal) seriously.
quotes: The biblical message is a great deal more complicated than 'Jesus accepts everybody.'
Lest your bonds be made strong; for I have heard a decree of destruction.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Explicitly connect the 'two ways' to the choice of building on the foundation stone versus the 'refuge of lies' in the current church crisis.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, identified as the cornerstone. However, the connection between the Old Testament 'alien work' and the Cross is made through systematic theology (Luther) rather than organic biblical theology from the text itself.
quotes: The cornerstone, the foundation that was laid, was Jesus Christ.
For the most alien work of all was the Cross of Christ, the stumbling stone.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how Christ *is* the 'alien work' in his suffering, rather than just stating it as a theological fact.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 15.5 minutes (1550 words), the sermon falls short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum requirement for 'breadth.' It lacks the necessary space to fully develop the exegesis alongside the heavy historical citations.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to reach the 20-minute mark, allowing the text to breathe before moving to Lincoln and Luther.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's standard primarily due to its length and a lack of original-language exegesis. It relies heavily on external theological authorities (Luther, Lincoln) rather than extracting the 'unique' word from the Isaiah text itself. However, it is strong in its refusal to succumb to modern sentimentality, maintaining the gravity of the 'two ways' and the reality of divine judgment.
strengths: Theologically sharp rejection of a 'soft' Gospel.
Concrete application to the contemporary ecclesiastical crisis.
Strong maintenance of the tension between God's alien and proper works.
weaknesses: Insufficient duration (under 20 minutes) to achieve 'depth through breadth'.
Lack of Hebrew exegesis and original historical context.
Over-reliance on historical anecdotes at the expense of textual exposition.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate theological speech, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the full sense of Dekker’s definition because the exposition of the specific Bible passage is secondary to the systematic-theological theme. It lacks the exegetical rigor and the required length to provide true homiletical depth.
